{{ad|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Camlin Fine Sciences Ltd. | logo = File:Camlin FS logo.png | caption = | type = [[Public Company|Public]] ({{BSE|532834}}) | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Mumbai]] | location_country = [[India]] | location = | locations = | area_served = South Asia, Mexico and Central America | key_people = [[Ashish Subhash Dandekar]] (Managing Director)<ref>https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/company/corporate-trends/meet-ashish-dandekar-the-camlin-scion-who-writes-his-own-success-story/articleshow/47824985.cms</ref> <ref name=aboutus>{{cite web|url=https://www.camlinfs.com/boards_committe.php|title=Camlin Fine Sciences - High quality shelf life extension solutions|website=www.camlinfs.com|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref> | industry = [[Speciality chemicals]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | traded_as = | homepage = [https://www.camlinfs.com www.camlinfs.com] | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''Camlin Fine Sciences Ltd.''', formerly known as Camlin Fine Chemicals Ltd., is a provider of [[shelf life]] [[solution]]s{{what|date=October 2018}}, aroma ingredients, and [[Performance-enhancing substance|performance chemicals]]. Led by Mr. Ashish Dandekar, Managing Director, CFS has emerged as the largest producer of food antioxidants like TBHQ [[tert-Butylhydroquinone]] and BHA [[Butylated hydroxyanisole]] and is also one of the world's leading Vanillin producer.<ref>http://fmtmagazine.in/news/camlin-fine-sciences-becomes-worlds-third-largest-vanillin-producer</ref> <ref>http://www.prnewswire.co.in/news-releases/a-night-to-remember-for-camlin-fine-chemicals-ltd-at-et-now-indiamart-leaders-of-tomorrow-awards-2011-135991698.html</ref>
CFS has offices and/or manufacturing facilities in several countries such as India, China, Italy, Brazil, Mexico and the United States.<ref>http://agrofoodpark.com/companies-in-agro-food-park/companies-in-agro-food-park/camlin-fine-sciences</ref> Having established global leadership in antioxidants, CFS forward integrated in blending{{what|date=October 2018}} and has a widened its application to food and beverage industry, petfood, animal feed, fishmeal, aquaculture, biodiesel etc.<ref>http://backoffice.phillipcapital.in/Backoffice/Researchfiles/Researchfilesmove/PC_-_Camlin_Fine_Science_Initiating_-_Mar_2016_20160331190624.pdf</ref>
Camlin Fine Sciences holds patent for improved process in synthesis of BHA [[Butylated hydroxyanisole]] from TBHQ [[tert-Butylhydroquinone]] <ref> https://patents.google.com/patent/WO2007015260A3/en</ref>
== History == In 1984, Camlin Fine Chemicals Division was started by [[Kokuyo Camlin|Camlin]] with the setting up of a new ultra modern plant at Tarapur, India.
In 2006, Camlin Fine Chemicals demerged from the parent company and an entirely new entity formed called 'Camlin Fine Sciences Ltd.
In 2007, CFS was listed on the [[Bombay Stock Exchange]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.camlinfs.com/journey.php|title=Camlin Fine Sciences - High quality shelf life extension solutions|website=www.camlinfs.com|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref>
In 2011, CFS got listed on the National Stock Exchange (NSE).
In 2011, CFS took the first overseas with the acquisition of Borregaard Italia SpA, a Hydroquinone and Catechol manufacturing facility at Ravenna, Italy through its wholly owned subsidiary in Mauritius.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/companies/camlin-fine-chemicals-buys-italyrsquos-borregaard/article23050272.ece|title=Camlin Fine Chemicals buys Italy’s Borregaard|publisher=|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref>
In 2014, CFS began operations in Brasil through its 100% subsidiary company CFS do Brasil Ltd, where it commenced production of antioxidant blends for food applications.
In 2016, CFS acquired 65 % stake in Dresen Quimica S.A.P.I.de C.V., Mexico along with its group companies and subsidiaries.
In July 2017, CFS became the 3rd largest producer of vanillin in the world with the acquisition of 51% stake in Ningbo Wanglong Flavors & Fragrances Company Ltd., China. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/camlin-fine-sciences-buys-51-stake-in-chinese-firm-117071201360_1.html|title=Camlin Fine Sciences buys 51% stake in Chinese firm|first=Press Trust of|last=India|date=12 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=11 May 2018|via=Business Standard}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vccircle.com/camlin-fine-sciences-buys-51-stake-in-chinese-chemical-firm/|title=Camlin Fine Sciences buys 51% stake in Chinese chemical firm|date=12 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/business/report-camlin-fine-sciences-buys-51-stake-in-chinese-firm-2500235|title=Camlin Fine Sciences buys 51% stake in Chinese firm - Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=12 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref>
In November 2017, CFS entered into a preferred supply agreement with Lockheed Martin Advanced Energy Storage for manufacturing and supply of a specialty chemical. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/announcements/camlin-fine-sciences-updates-2439367.html|title=Camlin Fine Sciences enters into agreement with Lockheed Martin Advanced Energy Storage|website=Moneycontrol|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://in.reuters.com/article/brief-camlin-fine-sciences-enters-prefer/brief-camlin-fine-sciences-enters-preferred-supply-agreement-with-lockheed-martin-advanced-energy-storage-idINFWN1NK1NF }}</ref> In April 2018, CFS entered into an Animal Nutrition joint venture with Pahang Pharma (S) Pte. Ltd., Singapore.
== Business Verticals == ===Shelf Life Solutions === Having established global leadership in antioxidants, CFS moved forward in blending by setting up a unit in Tarapur, India and in Brazil in 2014. <ref>http://backoffice.phillipcapital.in/Backoffice/Researchfiles/Researchfilesmove/PC_-_Camlin_Fine_Science_Initiating_-_Mar_2016_20160331190624.pdf</ref>Today, CFS has its blending facilities across the world (India, China, Mexico, USA and Brazil). It has a portfolio of more than 100 traditional and natural shelf life solution products under the brand names, Xtendra and NaSure. The Company has widened its applications for different food industries such as snacks, bakery, meat & poultry, spices & seasonings etc. and has also tapped potential shelf life [[solution]]s{{what|date=October 2018}} in fried snacks, pet food, fishmeal, biodiesel, confectionery, animal feed.<ref>https://www.indiainfoline.com/company/camlin-fine-sciences-ltd/management-discussions/27793</ref>
CFS acquired 65% stake in Dresen Quimica S.A.P.I. de C.V., Mexico, to cover Central America and Andean States. Dresen is in the Mexican food and feed blends business. With this acquisition, the portfolio expanded to geographies in Mexico and Central America with products like antioxidant blends (traditional and natural),feed additives etc.[https://www.livemint.com/Companies/xbaLjsEwmEmZeXoK1kpj2K/Camlin-Fine-Sciences-Mexican-unit-acquires-65-stake-in-Dre.html]
===Aroma Ingredients=== CFS produces vanillin and ethyl vanillin using fully traceable vertically integrated production.<ref>https://www.ingredientsnetwork.com/camlin-fine-sciences-comp248751.html</ref> CFS uses an environmentally friendly method for producing vanillin and ethyl vanillin (sold under the brand name Vanesse and Evanil respectively) from Catechol. The company makes all key ingredients in-house and has gained acceptance as a quality global vanillin player.<ref>https://www.indiainfoline.com/company/camlin-fine-sciences-ltd/management-discussions/27793</ref> The brands Vanesse (vanillin) and Evanil (ethyl vanillin) have grown their customer base not only from food and flavor industry, but also manufacturers of fragrances, incense sticks and pharmaceuticals industries and perfumeries.<ref>http://www.foodingredientsfirst.com/news/camlin-fine-sciences-becomes-worlds-third-largest-vanillin-producer.html</ref>
The company has also launched Floral booster, which is specially developed for incense stick industry to enhance sweet note, sustain burning and aroma-spreading properties along with Intense Green-a fragrance and flavour chemical, and Vetigreen-an aromatic chemical for home cleaning solutions, personal care products, cosmetics and incense sticks. <ref>http://corporateethos.com/corporate-domain/camlin-fine-sciences-acquires-51-in-china-firm-stock-hits-new-one-month-high</ref>
===Performance Chemicals=== The company entered into performance chemicals segment with the acquisition of Borregaard Italia Spa ltd in March 2011 and became one of the largest producers of di‐phenols (Hydroquinone and Catechol). To cater the demand from the market CFS has doubled its guaiacol capacity to 4000 [[Tonne]] per annum(tpa) and raised veratrole capacity by 67% to 1000tpa in FY16 and this will lead to 17% sales CAGR over FY15‐18 to Rs 2.04bn. <ref>http://backoffice.phillipcapital.in/Backoffice/Researchfiles/Researchfilesmove/PC_-_Camlin_Fine_Science_Initiating_-_Mar_2016_20160331190624.pdf</ref> CFS has a distribution hub in different parts of the world to cater to customer demands.

revision.text:
'''Cold hardening''' is the [[physiological]] and [[biochemical]] process by which an organism prepares for cold weather.
==Plants== [[File:Ice Storm 2013, Guelph 06.jpg|thumb|Plant covered in snow after an ice storm in 2013, Ontario, Canada]] Plants in [[Temperate climate|temperate]] and polar regions adapt to winter and sub zero temperatures by relocating [[nutrient]]s from leaves and shoots to [[storage organ]]s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Thorsen|first=Stig Morten|last2=Höglind|first2=Mats|date=2010-12-15|title=Modelling cold hardening and dehardening in timothy. Sensitivity analysis and Bayesian model comparison|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168192310002017|journal=Agricultural and Forest Meteorology|volume=150|issue=12|pages=1529–1542|doi=10.1016/j.agrformet.2010.08.001}}</ref> Freezing temperatures induce dehydrative [[Stress (biology)|stress]] on plants, as water absorption in the root and water transport in the plant decreases.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Smallwood|first=Maggie|last2=Bowles|first2=Dianna J.|date=2002-07-29|title=Plants in a cold climate|url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/357/1423/831|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=357|issue=1423|pages=831–847|doi=10.1098/rstb.2002.1073|issn=0962-8436|pmc=1692998|pmid=12171647}}</ref> Water in and between cells in the plant freezes and expands, causing tissue damage. Cold hardening is a process in which a plant undergoes physiological changes to avoid, or mitigate [[Cell (biology)|cellular]] injuries caused by sub-zero temperatures.<ref name=":0" /> Non-acclimatized individuals can survive −5 °C, while an acclimatized individual in the same species can survive −30°. Plants that originated in the tropics, like [[tomato]] or [[maize]], don't go through cold hardening and are unable to survive freezing temperatures.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=McKhann|first=Heather I.|last2=Gery|first2=Carine|last3=Bérard|first3=Aurélie|last4=Lévêque|first4=Sylvie|last5=Zuther|first5=Ellen|last6=Hincha|first6=Dirk K.|last7=De Mita|first7=S.|last8=Brunel|first8=Dominique|last9=Téoulé|first9=Evelyne|date=2008-01-01|title=Natural variation in CBF gene sequence, gene expression and freezing tolerance in the Versailles core collection of Arabidopsis thaliana|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/1471-2229-8-105|journal=BMC Plant Biology|volume=8|pages=105|doi=10.1186/1471-2229-8-105|issn=1471-2229|pmc=2579297|pmid=18922165}}</ref> The plant starts the [[Adaptation (biology)|adaptation]] by exposure to cold yet still not freezing temperatures. The process can be divided into three steps. First the plant perceives low temperature, then converts the [[Signal (biology)|signal]] to activate or repress [[Gene expression|expression]] of appropriate [[gene]]s. Finally, it uses these genes to combat the [[Stress (biology)|stress]], caused by sub-zero temperatures, affecting its living [[Cell (biology)|cells]]. Many of the genes and responses to low temperature [[Stress (biology)|stress]] are shared with other [[abiotic stress]]es, like drought or salinity.<ref name=":1" />[[Image:Plant cell structure-en.svg|thumb|200px|Schematic of typical plant cell]]When temperature drops, the [[Cell membrane|membrane]] fluidity, [[RNA]] and [[DNA]] stability, and [[enzyme]] activity change. These, in turn, affect [[Transcription (genetics)|transcription]], [[Translation (biology)|translation]], [[Metabolism|intermediate metabolism]], and [[photosynthesis]], leading to an energy imbalance. This energy imbalance is thought to be one of the ways the plant detects low temperature. Experiments on ''[[arabidopsis]]'' show that the plant detects the change in temperature, rather than the [[Thermodynamic temperature|absolute temperature]].<ref name=":1" /> The rate of temperature drop is directly connected to the magnitude of [[calcium]] influx, from the space between cells, into the cell. [[Calcium channel]]s in the [[cell membrane]] detect the temperature drop, and promotes expression of low temperature responsible genes in ''[[alfalfa]]'' and ''[[arabidopsis]]''. The response to the change in [[calcium]] elevation depends on the cell type and [[Stress (biology)|stress]] history. [[Shoot]] tissue will respond more than a [[root]] cells, and a cell that already is [[Adaptation|adapted]] <nowiki/>to [[Hypothermia|cold stress]] will respond more than one that has not been through cold hardening before. Light doesn't control the onset of cold hardening directly, but shortening of daylight is associated with fall, and starts production of [[reactive oxygen species]] and excitation of [[Photosystem II|photosystem 2]], which influences low-temp [[signal transduction]] mechanisms. Plants with compromised perception of day length have compromised cold acclimation.<ref name=":1" />
Cold increases [[Cell permeability|cell membrane permeability]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=itB5yKv7-rIC|title=Plants in Agriculture|last=Forbes|first=James C.|last2=Watson|first2=Drennan|date=1992-08-20|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521427913|language=en}}</ref> and makes the cell shrink, as water is drawn out when ice is formed in the [[extracellular matrix]] between cells.<ref name=":1" /> To retain the [[surface area]] of the [[cell membrane]] so it will be able to regain its former [[volume]] when temperature rises again, the plant forms more and stronger [[Hechtian strand]]s. These are tubelike structures that connect the [[protoplast]] with the cell wall. When the [[intracellular]] water freezes, the cell will expand, and without cold hardening the cell would rupture. To protect the cell membrane from expansion induced damage, the plant cell changes the proportions of almost all [[lipid]]s in the cell membrane, and increases the amount of total soluble [[protein]] and other cryoprotecting molecules, like sugar and [[proline]].<ref name=":2" />
Chilling injury occurs at 0–10 degrees Celsius, as a result of membrane damage, metabolic changes, and toxic buildup. Symptoms include wilting, water soaking, [[necrosis]], [[chlorosis]], ion leakage, and decreased growth. Freezing injury may occur at temperatures below 0 degrees Celsius. Symptoms of extracellular freezing include structural damage, dehydration, and necrosis. If intracellular freezing occurs, it will lead to death. Freezing injury is a result of lost permeability, plasmolysis, and post-thaw cell bursting.
When spring comes, or during a mild spell in winter, plants de-harden, and if the temperature is warm for long enough – their growth resumes.<ref name=":0" />
==Insects== Cold hardening has also been observed in [[insect]]s such as the [[Drosophila melanogaster|fruit fly]] and [[diamondback moth]]. The insects use rapid cold hardening to protect against [[cold shock]] during overwintering periods.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title=A rapid cold-hardening process in insects|last=Chen|first=CP|last2=Denlinger|first2=DL|journal=Science|last3=Lee|first3=RE|pmid=17800568|doi=10.1126/science.238.4832.1415|volume=238|issue=4832|pages=1415–7|year=1987}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=A rapid cold-hardening response protecting against cold shock injury in Drosophila melanogaster|last=Lee|first=RE|last2=Czajka|first2=MC|publisher=Science|pmid=2106564|volume=148|journal=J Exp Biol|pages=245–54|year=1990}}</ref> [[Overwintering]] insects stay awake and active through the winter while non-overwintering insects [[Insect migration|migrate]] or die. Rapid cold hardening can be experienced during short periods of undesirable temperatures, such as [[Cold shock response|cold shock]] in environment temperature, as well as the common cold months. The buildup of [[Cryoprotectant|cryoprotective]] compounds is the reason that insects can experience cold hardening.<ref name=":3" /> [[Glycerol]] is a cryoprotective substance found within these insects capable of overwintering. Through testing, glycerol requires interactions with other [[cell components]] within the insect in order to decrease the body's permeability to the cold.<ref name=":3" /> When an insect is exposed to these cold temperatures, glycerol rapidly accumulates. Glycerol is known as a [[non-ionic]] [[Kosmotropic|kosmotrope]] forming powerful [[hydrogen bond]]s with [[water molecule]]s. The hydrogen bonds in the glycerol compound compete with the weaker bonds between the water molecules causing an interruption in the makeup of ice formation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Duman | first1 = J | year = 2002 | title = The inhibition of ice nucleators by insect antifreeze proteins is enhanced by glycerol and citrate | url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00360-001-0239-7 | journal = Journal of Comparative Physiology B | volume = 172 | issue = 2| pages = 163–168 | doi = 10.1007/s00360-001-0239-7 }}</ref> This chemistry found within the glycerol compound and reaction between water has been used as an [[antifreeze]] in the past, and can be seen here when concerning cold hardening. Proteins also play a large role in the cryoprotective compounds that increase ability to survive the cold hardening process and environmental change. [[Glycogen phosphorylase]] (GlyP) has been a key protein found during testing to increase in comparison to a controlled group not experiencing the cold hardening.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Overgaard | first1 = J. | last2 = Sørensen | first2 = J. G. | last3 = Com | first3 = E. | last4 = Colinet | first4 = H. | year = 2013 | title = The rapid cold hardening response of Drosophila melanogaster: Complex regulation across different levels of biological organization | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022191014000109 | journal = Journal of Insect Physiology | volume = 62 | issue = | pages = 46–53 | doi=10.1016/j.jinsphys.2014.01.009| pmid = 24508557 }}</ref> Once warmer temperatures are observed the process of [[acclimation]] begins, and the increased glycerol along with other cryoprotective compounds and proteins are also reversed. There is a rapid cold hardening capacity found within certain insects that suggests not all insects can survive a long period of overwintering. Non-[[Diapause|diapausing]] insects can sustain brief temperature shocks but often have a limit to which they can handle before the body can no longer produce enough cryoprotective components. <nowiki/>[[File:Saving the planet one fruit fly at a time - part 1 (7353498896).jpg|thumb|The common fruit fly]] Inclusive to the cold hardening process being beneficial for insects survival during cold temperatures, it also helps improve the [[organism]]<nowiki/>s performance.<ref name=":4">{{cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Damodaran | first2 = K. | last3 = Yi | first3 = S. X. | last4 = Lorigan | first4 = G. A. | year = 2006 | title = Rapid Cold-Hardening Increases Membrane Fluidity and Cold Tolerance of Insect Cells | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011224006000526 | journal = Cryobiology | volume = 52 | issue = 3| pages = 459–463 | doi=10.1016/j.cryobiol.2006.03.003}}</ref> Rapid cold hardening (RCH) is one of the fastest cold temperature responses recorded.<ref name=":4" /> This process allows an insect to instantly adapt to the severe weather change without compromising function. The ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]]'' (common fruit fly) is a frequently experimented insect involving cold hardening. A proven example of RCH enhancing organisms performance comes from courting and mating within the fruit fly. It has been tested that the fruit fly mated more frequently once RCH has commenced in relation to a controlled insect group not experiencing RCH.<ref name=":4" /> Most insects experiencing extended cold periods are observed to modify the [[membrane lipids]] within the body. Desaturation of [[fatty acid]]s are the most commonly seen modification to the [[membrane]].<ref name=":4" /> When the fruit fly was observed under the stressful climate the survival rate increased in comparison to the fly prior to cold hardening. [[File:Plutella.xylostella.7383.jpg|thumb|The diamondback moth]] In addition to testing on the common fruit fly, ''[[Diamondback moth|Plutella xylostella]]'' (diamondback moth) also has been widely studied for its significance in cold hardening. While this insect also shows an increase in glycerol and similar cryoprotective compounds, it also shows an increase in [[polyol]]s. These compounds are specifically linked to cryoprotective compounds designed to withstand cold hardening. The polyol compound is freeze-susceptible and [[Freeze tolerance|freeze tolerant]].<ref name=":5">{{cite journal | last1 = Park | first1 = Y. | last2 = Kim | first2 = Y. | year = 2014 | title = A specific glycerol kinase induces rapid cold hardening of the diamondback moth, Plutella xylostella | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022191014001255 | journal = Journal of Insect Physiology | volume = 67 | issue = | pages = 56–63 | doi=10.1016/j.jinsphys.2014.06.010| pmid = 24973793 }}</ref> Polyols simply act as a barrier within the insect body by preventing [[intracellular]] freezing by restricting the [[extracellular]] freezing likely to happen in overwintering periods.<ref name=":5" /> During the larvae stage of the diamondback moth, the significance of glycerol was tested again for validity. The lab injected the larvae with added glycerol and in turn proved that glycerol is a major factor in survival rate when cold hardening. The cold tolerance is directly proportional to the buildup of glycerol during cold hardening.<ref name=":5" />
Cold hardening of insects improves the survival rate of the species and improves function. Once environmental temperature begins to warm up above freezing, the cold hardening process is reversed and the glycerol and cryprotective compounds decrease within the body. This also reverts the function of the insect to pre-cold hardening activity.
== See also == *[[Antifreeze protein]] *[[Cryobiology]] *[[Cryopreservation]]
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cold Hardening}} [[Category:Physiology]] [[Category:Plant physiology]] [[Category:Cryobiology]]

revision.text:
[[File:DeutschlandsenderIII.jpg|thumb|right|Mast in 1940]]The '''Deutschlandsender III''' was a 500 kilowatt [[longwave]] transmitter, erected in 1938/39 near [[Herzberg (Elster)|Herzberg]], [[Province of Brandenburg|Brandenburg]] in [[Germany]]. Used for the ''[[Deutschlandsender]]'' radio broadcasts, the [[guyed mast]] reaching a height of {{convert|337|m|ft|abbr=off}} was the tallest construction in Europe and the second tallest in the world.
==Construction== [[File:DeutschlandsenderIII Dach.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Mast head]] The Deutschlandsender III used a {{convert|325|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall guyed steel lattice mast of triangular cross section. This was used as a [[mast radiator]] and was therefore mounted on a {{convert|0.75|m|ft|abbr=on}} high [[Soapstone|steatite]] insulator. At the top of the mast there was a lens-like [[electrical length]]ening structure with a diameter of {{convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} and a height of {{convert|4|m|ft|abbr=on}}.
Because the mast was under high voltage during transmission, the [[aircraft warning lights|aircraft warning lighting]] was realized in a very unconventional manner. On small poles near the mast multiple rotating searchlights were mounted which illuminated the lens-like structure on the top.
It was planned to expand the facility to a circle group antenna. Therefore, ten {{convert|275|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall masts should be built on a circle with a diameter of {{convert|1425|m|ft|abbr=on}} around the central mast. In 1944 construction of a backup antenna in form of a triangle antenna, carried by three {{convert|150|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall masts, forming a triangle with {{convert|210|m|ft|abbr=on}} sidelength, started on the location of the planned mast No. 9. This antenna could not be completed as a result of the war.
On 21 April 1945 the transmitter was severely damaged by Allied bombing. The mast remained unimpaired, but, it dismantled by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation troops, a task that lasted from July 1946 to 23 December 1947. The other parts of the facility were dismantled in 1959, when waterworks were built on the former station area. Nevertheless, there are still some remnants of the base visible at the location.
It is unknown what happened to the mast after it was dismantled. It is sometimes claimed that it was rebuilt in the Ukraine, as "Kiev" was scrawled on the containers the components were transported in.
==See also== * [[List of masts]]
==External links== * {{Structurae|id=s0010713|title=Deutschlandsender Herzberg}} * http://www.skyscraperpage.com/diagrams/?b45271
{{coord|51|43|00|N|13|15|51|E|type:landmark_region:DE-BB_source:dewiki|display=title}}

revision.text:
'''Energy rationing''' primarily involves measures that are designed to force [[energy conservation]] as an alternative to [[price mechanism]]s in [[energy market]]s. Because of its economic consequences energy rationing is used as method of last resort, often at times of emergency such as during an [[energy crisis]].
==Forms== Examples of energy [[rationing]] include fuel rationing and the use of ration books or [[ration stamp]]s to restrict personal consumption. Energy rationing may include penalties such as [[fee|surcharges]] and disconnection from electrical supply for those who choose not to reduce their demand voluntarily.
[[Load shedding]] is a common form of energy rationing used when [[electricity market]]s cannot keep up to demand, particularly [[peak demand]]. Limited electrical supply from [[power station]]s at times of drought or after [[infrastructure]] is damaged, can lead authorities to implement rationing. [[Electricity_sector_in_Brazil#The_2001-2002_crisis_and_the_government.E2.80.99s_response|Brazil was forced]] to implement energy rationing due to drought in 2001.<ref name=lat>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/may/28/business/fi-3531 |title=Brazil’s Energy Rationing Aims to Cut Usage by 20% |author=Andrei Khalip |accessdate=2008-01-24 |date=2001-05-28 |work= |publisher=[[LA Times]] }}</ref> Reducing demand in this way aims to avoid forced [[power outage]]s which are more disruptive than rationing.<ref name=lat />
[[Tradable Energy Quotas]] is an energy rationing system designed to enable nations to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases along with their use of oil, gas and coal, and to ensure fair access to energy for all.
==Issues== {{main|Energy security}} One issue with energy rationing is the cost of setting up a rationing schemes. Another criticism is that energy rationing schemes are unworkable and face many practical problems including consumer lawsuits.<ref name=lat /> Due to the general disdain for restrictions that interfere with existing personal freedoms, such as [[ecotax]]es and [[carbon rationing]], energy rationing is not favoured by policy makers to [[Mitigation of global warming|mitigate global warming]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/05/29/carbon_rationing_no/ |title=Are you ready for WW2-style energy rationing? |author=Andrew Orlowski |accessdate=2008-01-24 |date=2008-05-29 |work= |publisher=[[The Register]] }}</ref>
===Peak oil=== {{main|Mitigation of peak oil}} As oil becomes more scarce due to [[oil depletion]] countries that have reserve currencies will prefer to buy oil rather than ration it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.321energy.com/editorials/price/price062908.html |title=Tribute Paid in Oil |accessdate=2008-06-30 |work=321energy.com }}</ref> The [[Oil Depletion Protocol]] is form of energy rationing that was developed by [[Richard Heinberg]] to ensure that price rationing does not price out poorer countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://globalpublicmedia.com/want_cheap_oil_reduce_demand |title=Want Cheap Oil? Reduce Demand! |accessdate=2008-07-09 |format= |work= }}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Energy}} *[[Energy descent]] *[[Energy efficient use]] *[[Food rationing]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Energy Rationing}} [[Category:Energy economics]] [[Category:Electric power distribution]] [[Category:Rationing]]

revision.text:
In [[topology]], a branch of mathematics, an '''excisive triad''' is a triple <math>(X; A, B)</math> of [[topological space]]s such that ''A'', ''B'' are subspaces of ''X'' and ''X'' is the union of the interior of ''A'' and the interior of ''B''.<ref>{{harvnb|May|loc=Ch 10. Section 7.}}</ref> Note ''B'' is not required to be a [[Subspace topology|subspace]] of ''A''.
== See also == *[[Homotopy excision theorem]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
== References == *J. P. May, A concise course in algebraic topology *[[James Munkres|Munkres, James]]; ''Topology'', Prentice Hall; 2nd edition (December 28, 1999). {{ISBN|0-13-181629-2}}.
{{topology-stub}} [[Category:Topology]] [[Category:General topology]]

revision.text:
[[File:February 18, 1952 nor'easter map.jpg|right|thumb|250px|A [[surface weather analysis]] of the nor'easter]] The '''February 1952 nor'easter''' was a significant [[winter storm]] that impacted the [[New England]] region of the United States. The storm ranked as Category 1, or "notable", on the [[Northeast Snowfall Impact Scale]].<ref name="Kocin2">Kocin and Uccellini, p. 659</ref> Its rapid intensification resulted in heavy snowfall between February 17 and 18, accumulating to {{convert|12|to|30|in|cm}}. High winds also affected central and northern New England. The nor'easter is estimated to have caused 42 fatalities. In [[Maine]], over 1,000 travelers became stranded on roadways.<ref name="Kocin3">Kocin and Uccellini, p. 660</ref> Two ships cracked in two offshore New England during the storm.
==Development== The development of this [[extratropical cyclone]] was associated with a pronounced weakening of the usual zonal, or west-to-east, flow which dominates the Mid-Latitudes during the winter, with the [[jet stream]] dipping from the latitude of Boston to the latitude of Charleston, South Carolina. The initial [[low-pressure area]] originated in the Gulf of Mexico, with a downstream redevelopment offshore Cape Hatteras on February 16. The cyclone deepened rapidly, 25 millibars in 24 hours between February 17 and February 18, while moving just offshore Long Island and southern New England, and dropped heavy precipitation across the central and northern [[Mid-Atlantic states]]. The snowfall associated with the storm across eastern New York and southern [[New England]] produced the heaviest snows of the winter.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Monthly Weather Review|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/080/mwr-080-02-0026.pdf|title=The Weather and Circulation of February 1952: A Month With a Pronounced Index Cycle|author=Jay S. Winston|pages=26-LXXX 25|publisher=American Meteorological Society|volume=80|number=2|doi=10.1175/1520-0493-80.2.26|bibcode=1952MWRv...80...26W}}</ref>
==Impact== [[Image:Pendleton Sinking Ship.jpg|thumb|right|Bow of the Pendleton]] {{See also|SS Pendleton}} There was significant disruption to shipping due to this storm. On February 18, 1952, while en route from [[New Orleans]] to [[Boston]], the [[T2 tanker]] SS Pendleton' broke in two in a [[nor'easter]] south of [[Cape Cod]], [[Massachusetts]].<ref name=VisserT2-SE-A1>{{cite web |last1=Visser |first1=Auke |title=Pendleton |url=http://www.aukevisser.nl/t2tanker/id246.htm |website=Auke Visser's Famous T – Tankers Pages |publisher=Auke Visser |accessdate=September 30, 2014 }}</ref> A [[United States Coast Guard]] [[Consolidated PBY Catalina]] aircraft was diverted from searching for another T2 tanker {{SS|Fort Mercer||2}} to search for ''Pendleton'', and located both sections. At this point, the Coast Guard realized that they were dealing with two ships that had broken in two. The ''[[Coast Guard Motor Lifeboat CG 36500]]'' was dispatched from [[Chatham, Massachusetts]]. She had four crew on board as the rest of her crew had made themselves scarce on hearing that the {{convert|36|ft|m|adj=on}} ''CG-36500'' was to be sent out to ''Pendleton{{'}}s'' aid.<ref name=USCG>{{cite web |url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/articles/Pendleton_Webster.asp |title=The Pendleton Rescue |first=W. Russell |last=Webster |publisher=United States Coast Guard |date=December 2001 |accessdate=October 1, 2014}}</ref> Nine of ''Pendleton{{'}}s'' 41 crew were lost, eight were on the bow section and the ship's cook from the stern section,<ref name=Wreck>{{cite web |last1=Visser |first1=Auke |title=Pendleton Wreck |url=http://www.aukevisser.nl/t2tanker/id916.htm |website=Auke Visser's Famous T – Tankers Pages |publisher=Auke Visser |accessdate=September 30, 2014 }}</ref> who had selflessly assisted the rest of the crew off the vessel before him. He was lost when, as the ship started to slide off a sand bar (that she landed on) by the strong gale-force winds, he jumped from the Jacob's ladder, fell into the ocean, and was struck by the lifeboat as it was hit by a wave, killing him instantly. With the survivors on board, a row developed over how they should be dealt with. [[Bernard C. Webber]], of the ''CG-36500'' decided not to transfer them to {{USCGC|McCulloch|WAVP-386|6}} and headed for the beach. The survivors were safely landed at Chatham.<ref name=USCG/>
The rescue of the survivors of the shipwrecked Pendleton is considered one of the most daring rescues of the United States Coast Guard.<ref name="uscg pendleton Rescue">{{cite web|title=Pendleton Rescue|url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/Pendleton_Index.asp|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|accessdate=September 30, 2014}}</ref> All four crew of ''CG-36500'' were awarded the Coast Guard's [[Gold Lifesaving Medal]].<ref name=Wreck/> At the time of her loss, ''Pendleton'' was insured for [[United States Dollar|$1,690,000]].<ref name=Times200252>{{Cite news |newspaper=[[The Times]] |title=American Shipping Casualties |date=February 20, 1952 |page=9 |issue=52240 }}</ref>
The stern ultimately grounded off [[Monomoy Island]], south of Chatham, and her forepart grounded on [[Pollock Rip Shoal]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/czm/buar/shipwrecks/boats/pendleton.html|title=Pendleton|author=czm|work=Energy and Environmental Affairs|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> at coordinates {{Coord|41|35|10|N|69|57|45|W|display=}},<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mwdc.org/Shipwrecks/Pendleton.html|title=Pendleton|publisher= MWDC|accessdate=October 16, 2016}}</ref> The bow section was sold in 1953 to North American Smelting Co. for recycling at [[Bordentown, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aukevisser.nl/t2tanker/id246.htm|title=Pendleton|publisher=|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> However, it was stranded on June 4, 1953 in the [[Delaware River]] and dismantled there c.1978 by the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]].<ref name=VisserT2-SE-A1/>
==In film== The movie [[The Finest Hours (2016 film)]] was based on a shipping mishap that occurred during this cyclone.
==See also== {{portal|Weather}} *[[Climate of the United States]] *[[List of NESIS storms]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} * {{cite book|author=Paul J. Kocin and Louis W. Uccellini|title=Northeast Snowstorms|year=2004|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|isbn=1-878220-64-0}}
{{United States winter storms}}
[[Category:Nor'easters]] [[Category:1952 meteorology]] [[Category:1952 natural disasters in the United States]] [[Category:February 1952 events]] [[Category:1952 in Maine]]

revision.comment: /* Fuel Duty Stabiliser */ Fixed typo
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Use British English|date=January 2015}} The '''Fuel Price Escalator''' (later '''Fuel Duty Stabiliser'''), a [[Hydrocarbon Oil Duty|fuel duty]] policy in the [[United Kingdom]] ahead of inflation, was introduced in March 1993 as a measure to stem the increase in pollution from road transport and cut the need for new road building at a time of major road protests, at [[Twyford Down]] and other locations. Set initially at 3% above inflation it was increased in two stages to 6% before being suspended and then, in 2011, replaced by a 'fuel duty stabiliser' (also known as the 'fuel price stabiliser' and 'fair fuel stabiliser') following further increases the price of oil.
==History==
===Fuel Price Escalator=== At a time of rapidly rising concerns about the effect of road transport on the environment, and in particular from the program of road building which had resulted in major road protests, at [[Twyford Down]] and other locations, the [[Second Major ministry|Conservative's under John Major]] introduced a 'Fuel Price Escalator' in March 1993 set initially at 3% ahead of inflation per year, increased to 5% later in the same year, and then increased again to 6% in 1997 by the [[Blair ministry]] after Labour won power.<ref name=briefing>{{cite web|url=http://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/SN03015/SN03015.pdf|title=Taxation of road fuels: the road fuel escalator (1993-2000)|publisher=[[House of Commons Library]]|date=2011-01-21}}</ref>
The last rise due to the escalator took place following the budget on 9 March 1999 at a time of rapidly increasing oil prices.<ref name=briefing/> In 2000 at a time of rising [[Fuel protests in the United Kingdom|protests at the cost of fuel]] Gordon Brown announced that the prices would only be increased by inflation due to the [[Price of oil|high price of oil]].<ref name=briefing/>
===Fuel Duty Stabiliser=== Increases were deferred for a number of budgets and then in 2011, at a time of rapidly increasing oil prices, [[George Osborne]] cut 1p from the tax, increased the [[Petroleum Revenue Tax]] to raise at additional £2bn from North Sea oil firms, and announced that the escalator would be replaced with a 'fuel price stabiliser'.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12829433|title=Budget 2011 at a glance: George Osborne's key points|work=BBC News|date=2011-03-24}}</ref> but would rise if oil prices fell below $75.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/budget/8402423/Duty-cut-as-Chancellor-unveils-fair-fuel-stabiliser.html|title=Duty cut as Chancellor unveils fair fuel stabiliser|work=The Telegraph|date=2011-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/11376849/Fuel-duty-rise-could-slow-fall-in-petrol-price-says-minister.html|title=Fuel duty may still rise despite fall in oil prices, says minister|work=The Telegraph|date=2015-01-29}}</ref>
In 2011 budget the Chancellor had also announced a rise of 1p in January 2012 and then 5p in August 2013, but later cancelled the 1p rise and reduced the 5p August rise to 3p in November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accountancyage.com/aa/news/2128520/as2011-fuel-duty-rise-cancelled|title=AS2011: Fuel duty rise cancelled|work=Accountancy Age|date=2011-11-29}}</ref> In the budget of 2012 Osborne confirmed the 3p August rise, before first postponing it and then cancelling it in December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2012/dec/05/george-osborne-fuel-duty-autumn-statement|title=George Osborne freezes fuel duty in autumn statement|work=The Guardian|date=2012-12-05}}</ref> A further proposed inflation-based increase in fuel duty was cancelled by the chancellor in March 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21858399|title=Budget 2013: Fuel duty rise cancelled by chancellor|work=BBC News|date=2013-03-20}}</ref>
In March 2016, with oil prices at about $40 a barrel,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/oil-price/60838/oil-price-stuck-as-iea-brands-supply-deal-meaningless|title=Oil price rally 'has run its course for now'|work=The Week|date=2016-03-24}}</ref> and following widespread speculation that the duty would be increased at a time of record low oil prices,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tax/news/budget-2016-how-osborne-could-increase-fuel-duty/|title=Budget 2016: how Osborne could increase fuel duty|work=The Telegraph|date=2016-03-15}}</ref> the chancellor froze fuel duty for the sixth year running,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fleetnews.co.uk/news/fleet-industry-news/2016/03/16/chancellor-freezes-fuel-duty-and-continues-to-consult-on-company-car-tax|title=Chancellor freezes fuel duty and continues to consult on company car tax|work=Fleet News|date=2016-03-16}}</ref> and reduced the tax on North Sea oil firms.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-35817176|title=Budget 2016: Chancellor George Osborne cuts North Sea taxes|work=BBC News}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Energy policy of the United Kingdom]] *[[Energy use and conservation in the United Kingdom]] *[[Elasticity (economics)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *[http://www.fsb.org.uk/LegacySitePath/policy/rpu/ni/images/fuel%20duty%20stabiliser.pdf A Fuel Duty Stabiliser – is it really that complicated?] *{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/SN04712.pdf|title=Petrol and Diesel Prices - Research briefing|publisher=House of Commons Library|date=2016-03-17}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Geoffrey G. Parker | image = [[File:Geoffrey-G-Parker-Portrait.jpg | 200px|center | Professor Geoffrey Parker, Thayer School of Engineering, Dartmouth College also serves as Director of the Master of Engineering Management program.]] | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Dayton, Ohio]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = United States of America | ethnicity = | fields = [[Management Science]]
[[Information Economics]] | workplaces = [[Dartmouth College]]
[[Tulane University]]
[[MIT Center for Digital Business]] | alma_mater = {{flatlist| *[[Princeton University|Princeton]] *[[MIT]]}} | notable_students = | doctoral_students = | notable_awards = | known_for = [[Two-sided market]]s | students = | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Geoffrey G Parker''' is a scholar whose work focuses on [[Open innovation|distributed innovation]], [[Energy economics|energy markets]], and the [[Information economics|economics of information]]. He co-developed the theory of [[two-sided market]]s with [[Marshall Van Alstyne]]. His current research includes studies of platform business strategy, data governance, and technical/economic systems to integrate distributed energy resources. Parker is Professor of Engineering and Director, Master of Engineering Management, (MEM) Thayer School of Engineering at Dartmouth College, the first national research university to graduate a class of engineers with more women than men. He has set the Thayer School of Engineering apart with the introduction of Data Analytics and Platform Design classes, emphasizing the business aspects of engineering and giving engineers the background they need to be business innovators and entrepreneurs. Parker is part of a unique culture that is breaking gender barriers. Parker is also a Faculty Fellow at MIT and the [[MIT Center for Digital Business]].{{cite web|url=http://mitsloan.mit.edu/ide/people/|title=Meet the IDE Team|publisher=MIT Initiative on the Digital Economy|accessdate=30 January 2016}} Parker is co-author of the book ''Platform Revolution'', which was included among the 16 must-read business books for 2016 by [[Forbes]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidburkus/2016/01/10/16-must-read-business-books-for-2016/#196c013148ba|title=16 Must-Read Business Books For 2016|author=David Burkus|date=10 January 2016|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=30 January 2016}} ==Early life and education== Geoffrey Parker was born in [[Dayton, Ohio]]. He received a BS in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from [[Princeton University]] in 1986. He then completed the General Electric Company Financial Management Training Program and held multiple positions in engineering and finance at [[General Electric]] in North Carolina and Wisconsin. He obtained an MS in [[Electrical Engineering]] (Technology and Policy Program) in 1993 and a PhD in [[Management Science]] in 1998, both at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].{{cite web|url=http://engineering.dartmouth.edu/people/faculty/geoffrey-parker/|title=Geoffrey G. Parker|publisher=Thayer School of Engineering at Dartmouth|accessdate=30 January 2016}} ==Career== Parker is Professor of Engineering and [https://engineering.dartmouth.edu/academics/graduate/mem Director, Master of Engineering Management], [https://engineering.dartmouth.edu Thayer School of Engineering], [[Dartmouth College]]. In addition, he is a Fellow at MIT’s Initiative on the Digital Economy where he leads platform industry research studies and co-chairs the annual [http://ide.mit.edu/events/2018-platform-strategy-summit MIT Platform Strategy Summit]. Parker is a visiting scholar at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] Sloan School. His teaching includes platform strategy courses that provide managers the tools they need to understand the digital economy and technical courses that give students the skills they need to transform [[Computational statistics|large data sets]] into actionable knowledge.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108232748/http://tulane.edu/news/newwave/060215_analytics_new_mba_concentration.cfm|title=Tulane University - New concentration helps MBAs make sense of big data|last=Miester|first=Mark|date=2016-01-08|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-20}} He was formerly Professor of Management Science at [[Tulane University]] where he served as Director of the [https://freeman.tulane.edu/content/tulane-energy-institute-tulane-freeman-business-school Tulane Energy Institute]. Parker has taught undergraduate and full-time [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] courses as well as professional MBA and executive MBA programs.{{Cite news|url=https://gsm.ucdavis.edu/post/geoffrey-g-parker|title=Geoffrey G. Parker - UC Davis Graduate School of Management|work=UC Davis Graduate School of Management|access-date=2018-06-20|language=en}} [[File:Geoffrey Parker.jpg|thumb|Geoffrey G. Parker lectures. Photo taken by L. Barry Hetherington]] Parker served as a National Science Foundation panelist from 2009 to 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://freemanblog.freeman.tulane.edu/freemanmag/2011/08/25/faculty-in-brief-4/|title=Research: Faculty Research in Brief|last=Freeman|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} He is a senior editor for the journal ''Production and Operations Management'', an associate editor for the journal ''Management Science''{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924214925/http://ebusiness.mit.edu/about/fellows.html|title=Digital Business at MIT {{!}} About - Fellows|date=2011-09-24|access-date=2018-06-20}} and President of the Industry Studies Association.{{Cite web|url=http://www.industrystudies.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=53|title=Geoff Parker, ISA Board of Directors|last=Deal|first=Michael|date=|website=www.industrystudies.org|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-20}} Parker is a member of [[General Electric]]’s Learning Advisory Board, consisting of academics drawn from across Africa, the United States of America and the United Kingdom, that assists in development and broadening of skills across Africa.{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201401291741.html|title=GE Launches the First GE Africa Learning Advisory Board with Focus on Local Technical Skills Development|date=2014-01-29|work=GE Africa (Lagos)|access-date=2018-06-20}} Parker co-organizes and co-chairs the annual [http://ide.mit.edu/events/2018-platform-strategy-summit-0 MIT Platform Strategy Summit], an executive meeting on platform-centered economics and management, where he stressed the growth of platforms, their [[Welfare economics|welfare implications]] and their takeover of government functions.{{Cite news|url=http://alisterpaine.com/2015/08/05/heres-what-you-missed-at-mits-2nd-annual-platform-strategy-summit/|title=Here’s What You Missed at MIT’s 3rd Annual Platform Strategy Summit|date=2015-08-05|work=Alister & Paine|access-date=2018-06-20|language=en-US}} At the same time, he co-chairs an academic meeting, the Platform Strategy Research Symposium.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecge.net/video/reflections-on-the-boston-platform-strategy-summits/|title=Reflections on the Boston Platform Strategy Summits - The Center for Global Enterprise|work=The Center for Global Enterprise|access-date=2018-06-20|language=en-US}} Parker served as chair of the U.S.-Israel Energy Summit in 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://ide.mit.edu/events/2018-platform-strategy-summit-0|title=2018 Platform Strategy Summit {{!}} MIT Initiative on the Digital Economy|website=ide.mit.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}} == Work == Parker has made significant contributions to the field of [[network economics]] and strategy as co-developer of the theory of [[two-sided market]]s with [[Marshall Van Alstyne]].{{cite web |ssrn = 249585 |title = Information Complements, Substitutes, and Strategic Product Design |publisher = Social Science Research Network |author1=Geoffrey Parker |author2=Marshall W. Van Alstyne |date = 8 November 2000 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}}{{cite web |url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=352883 |title = Internetwork externalities and free information goods |publisher = ACM Conference Proceedings |author1=Geoffrey Parker |author2=Marshall W. Van Alstyne |date = 2000 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}}{{cite web |ssrn = 1177443 |title = Two-Sided Network Effects: A Theory of Information Product Design |publisher = Management Science |author1=Geoffrey Parker |author2=Marshall W. Van Alstyne |date = 29 September 2009 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}} Parker and Van Alstyne observed that, unlike traditional value chains with cost and revenue on different sides, two-sided networks have cost and revenue on both sides, because the “platform” has a distinct group of users on each side.{{cite web |url = http://bizshifts-trends.com/2014/11/09/two-sided-markets-two-sided-networks-yin-yang-business-models-works-google-ebay-amazon-apple-microsoft/ |title = Two-Sided Markets, Two-Sided Networksb & The Yin-Yang of Business Models: Works for Google, eBay, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft. |publisher = BizShifts-Trends |date = 9 November 2014 |accessdate = 30 January 2016}} Their approach has been described as the “chicken and egg” problem of how to build a platform.{{cite web |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/henrychesbrough/2011/05/09/competing-for-contributors-in-open-innovation/#5bc07fe332c9 |title = Competing for Contributors in Open Innovation |publisher = Forbes |author = Henry Chesbrough |date = 9 May 2011 |accessdate = 30 January 2016}} They concluded that the problem must be solved by platform owners, typically by cross-subsidizing between groups or even giving away products or services for free.{{cite book |last=Gawer |first=Annabelle |date=2009 |title=Platforms, Markets and Innovation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1BvhQT8SHZkC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Google Books |publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing Limited |page=21 |isbn=9781848440708}} Two-sided network effects can cause markets to concentrate in the hands of a few firms. These properties inform the strategies and antitrust law approaches at all firms involved in the network. His research includes studies of [[open innovation|distributed innovation]],{{cite web |url = http://sloanreview.mit.edu/article/succeed-in-distributed-product-development/ |title = Putting It Together: How to Succeed in Distributed Product Development |publisher = MIT Sloan Review |author1=Jason Amaral |author2=Edward G. Anderson Jr. |author3=Geoffrey G. Parker |date = 21 December 2010 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}} business platform strategy,{{cite journal |url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.935/abstract |title = Platform envelopment |journal = Strategic Management Journal |author1=Thomas Eisenmann |author2=Geoffrey Parker |author3=Marshall Van Alstyne |date = December 2011 |accessdate = 31 January 2016 |doi=10.1002/smj.935 |volume=32 |pages=1270–1285}} and platforms to integrate intermittent energy.{{cite web |ssrn = 1531748 |title = Efficiency of Financial Transmission Rights Markets in Centrally Coordinated Periodic Auctions |publisher = Energy Economics |author1=Seabron Adamson |author2=Thomas H. Noe |author3=Geoffrey Parker |date = 15 March 2010 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}} Parker is a frequent keynote speaker and advises senior leaders on their organizations’ platform strategies. Before attending MIT, he held positions in engineering and finance at GE. == Publications == Parker’s research has appeared in journals such as [[Harvard Business Review|''Harvard Business Review'']], [[MIT Sloan Management Review|''MIT Sloan Management Review'']], ''[https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1531748 Energy Economics]'', [[Information Systems Research|''Information Systems Research'']]'', [[Journal of Economics & Management Strategy|Journal of Economics and Management Strategy]],'' ''[https://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/10.1287/mnsc.2017.2757 Management Science]'', ''[[doi:10.1111/j.1937-5956.2000.tb00136.x|Production and Operations Management]]'', and ''[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/smj.935 Strategic Management Journal]''. His work has also been featured on business news publications such as [https://www.marketwatch.com/ “MarketWatch”] and "[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]".{{cite web |url = https://hbr.org/2006/10/strategies-for-two-sided-markets |title = Strategies for two-sided markets |publisher = Harvard Business Review |date = October 2006 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}}{{cite web |url = http://www.marketwatch.com/story/what-twitter-knows-that-blackberry-didnt-2013-10-10 |title = What Twitter knows that Blackberry didn't |publisher = Marketwatch |author1=Sangeet Paul Choudary |author2=Geoffrey Parker |author3=Marshall Van Alstyne |date = 10 October 2013 |accessdate = 31 January 2016}} He is the co-author of ''Platform Revolution: How Networked Markets Are Transforming the Economy and How to Make Them Work for You''.{{cite web |url = http://books.wwnorton.com/books/detail.aspx?id=4294989879 |title = Platform Revolution |publisher = W. W. Norton |accessdate = 30 January 2016}} The book describes the [[Information technology|information technologies]], standards, and rules that make up platforms, and are used and developed by the biggest and most innovative global companies.{{cite web |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/21/technology/techs-frightful-5-will-dominate-digital-life-for-foreseeable-future.html?_r=0 |title = Tech's Frightful 5 Will Dominate Digital Life for Foreseeable Future |publisher = The New York Times |author = Farhad Manjoo |date = 20 January 2016 |accessdate = 29 January 2016}} [[Forbes]] included it among 16 must-read business books for 2016, describing it as "a practical guide to the new business model that is transforming the way we work and live." Parker also co-wrote ''Operations Management For Dummies'' within the ''[[For Dummies]]'' franchise.{{cite web |url = http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118551060.html |title = Operations Management For Dummies |publisher = Wiley |accessdate = 30 January 2016}} == Excerpts == [http://fortune.com/2016/04/10/nike-platform-business-book-excerpt/ Fortune’s Excerpt of Platform Revolution: How Networked Markets Are Transforming the Economy and How to Make Them Work for You] [http://sloanreview.mit.edu/article/tech-savvy-is-it-time-to-build-your-own-platform/ MIT Sloan Management Review: The Intersection of Management and Technology] == Awards == Parker won the Wick Skinner Early Career Research Accomplishments Award in 2003.{{cite web |url = http://www.poms.org/chronicle/Vol10No1.pdf |title = The Wick Skinner Awards: Rewarding Productivity, Innovation, and Communication |publisher = POMS Chronicle |author = Robert H Hayes |page = 5 |date = June 2003 |accessdate = 30 January 2016}} He was given the Dean’s Excellence in Teaching Award for Graduate Education at [[Freeman School of Business]] in 2014.{{cite web |url = http://freemanblog.freeman.tulane.edu/freemannews/2014/10/07/five-faculty-members-honored-with-awards/ |title = Five faculty members honored with awards |publisher = Freeman News |date = 7 October Erzurumlu, N. Joglekar, G. Parker (2007). “[http://ssrn.com/abstract=1259382 The Effects of Outsourcing, Offshoring, and Distributed Product Development Organization on Coordinating the NPD Process.]” Chapter in Handbook on New Product Development. Eds. C. Loch, S. Kavadias. # Eisenmann, T., G. Parker, M. Van Alstyne (2006). “[http://hbr.org/2006/10/strategies-for-two-sided-markets/ar/1 Strategies for Two-Sided Markets.]” ''Harvard Business Review,'' Vol. 84, No. 10. # Parker, G. and M. Van Alstyne (2005). “[http://ssrn.com/abstract=1177443 Two-Sided Network Effects: A Theory of Information Product Design.]” ''Management Science'', Vol. 51, No. 10. # Noe, T. and G. Van Alstyne (2005). “[https://www.computer.org/csdl/proceedings/hicss/2005/2268/08/22680213b.pdf Mechanism Design to Promote Free Market and Open Source Software Innovation]” IEEE Computer Society: Proceedings of the 38th Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences. # Anderson, E.G. and G. Parker (2002). “[http://ssrn.com/abstract=1938417 The Effect of Learning on the Make/Buy Decision.]” ''Production and Operations Management'', Vol. 11, No. 3. #[http://ssrn.com/abstract=1259372 Parker, G.G. and E.G. Anderson (2002). “From Buyer to Integrator: The Transformation of the Supply Chain Manager in the Vertically Disintegrating Firm.]” ''Production and Operations Management'', Vol 11, No. 1. # Parker, G., E. Anderson (2001), “Supply Chain Integration: Putting Humpty-Dumpty Back Together Again,” Chapter in [https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/stores/detail/-/books/0814406378/reviews/qid%3D1002208177/103-7306394-7604660 New Directions in Supply-Chain Management: Technology, Strategy, and Implementation.] # Anderson, E. G. Jr., C. Fine, and G. {{refimprove|date=January 2011}} {{redirect|H̃|the sound with symbol h̃|Voiceless nasal glottal approximant}} {{Standard model of particle physics}} In [[particle physics]], for models with N=1 supersymmetry a '''Higgsino''', symbol {{SubatomicParticle|Higgsino}}, is the [[superpartner]] of the [[Higgs boson|Higgs field]]. A Higgsino is a [[Dirac fermion]]ic field with spin 1/2 and it refers to a [[Weak isospin|weak isodoublet]] with hypercharge half under the Standard Model gauge symmetries. After [[electroweak symmetry breaking]] higgsino fields linearly mix with U(1) and SU(2) gauginos leading to four [[Neutralino|neutralinos]] and two [[Chargino|charginos]] resulting from electroweak symmetry breaking of the [[Bino (particle)|bino]] and [[Wino (particle)|wino]] 0, 1, 2 that refer to physical particles. While the two charginos are charged Dirac fermions (plus and minus each), the neutralinos are electrically neutral [[Majorana fermion]]s. In an [[R-parity]] conserving version of the [[Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model]], the lightest neutralino typically becomes the [[lightest supersymmetric particle]] (LSP). The LSP is a particle physics candidate for the [[dark matter]] of the universe since it cannot decay to particles with lighter mass. A neutralino LSP, depending on its composition can be bino, wino or higgsino dominated in nature http://pdg.lbl.gov/2017/reviews/rpp2017-rev-susy-1-theory.pdf and can have different zones of mass values in order to satisfy the estimated dark matter relic density. Commonly, a higgsino dominated LSP is often referred as a higgsino, in spite of the fact that a higgsino is not a physical state in true sense. In [[naturalness (physics)|natural]] scenarios of SUSY, [[stop squark|top squarks]], bottom squarks, [[gluinos]], and higgsino-enriched neutralinos and charginos are expected to be relatively light, enhancing their production cross sections. Higgsino searches have been performed by both the [[ATLAS experiment|ATLAS]] and [[Compact Muon Solenoid|CMS]] experiments at the [[Large Hadron Collider]] at [[CERN]], where physicists have searched for the direct electroweak pair production of Higgsinos. As of 2017, no experimental evidence for Higgsinos has been reported.{{cite web|url=https://atlas.web.cern.ch/Atlas/GROUPS/PHYSICS/CombinedSummaryPlots/SUSY/|title=ATLAS Supersymmetry Public Results| publisher=ATLAS, CERN |date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}}{{cite web|url=https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/view/CMSPublic/PhysicsResultsSUS|title=CMS Supersymmetry Public Results| publisher=CMS, CERN |date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}} == Mass == If dark matter is composed only of Higgsinos, then the Higgsino mass is 1.1 [[electronvolt|TeV]]. On the other hand, if dark matter has multiple components, then the Higgsino mass depends on the relevant multiverse distribution functions, making the mass of the Higgsino lighter.
::mħ ≈ 1.1(Ωħ/ΩDM)½ TeVLawrence J. Hall and Yasunori Nomura, [https://arxiv.org/pdf/1111.4519.pdf "Spread Supersymmetry"], ''Berkeley Center for Theoretical Physics, Department of Physics, and Theoretical Physics Group, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA'', 19 Nov 2011 == Footnotes == {{particles}} [[Category:Supersymmetry]] [[Category:Fermions]] [[Category:Hypothetical elementary particles]]
